title: Introducing python-in-browser
body:
Python-in-browser is a project I have been working on which allows you to run Python code in your browser, sandboxed away from your system.
 
I was inspired by https://github.com/raxod502/python-in-a-box, but python-in-browser has very few things in common. 
Python-in-a-box runs Python code on a server, so it has access to most of the good Python featues.
Python-in-browser parses Python code in your browser, so it lacks most of those features. 
The only good thing about Python-in-browser is the fact that it sends no requests to a server, so it works offline. (to some degree, and the page must be loaded with an internet connection)
Python-in-browser can be found at https://iam-py-test.github.io/python-in-browser, and the source code is at https://github.com/iam-py-test/python-in-browser

title: Why should you use NoScript?
body:
NoScript is a browser extention which allows you to selectivly allow or deny scripts. NoScript also provides protection against XSS (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/xss), but I have never seen it block a real attack. 
However, its XSS protection was able to block all of the XSS tests I knew and all of the OWASP advanced ones I tested.

title: Tracking down fake Firefoxs
body:
The first results on a quick search 'Download firefox' are from Mozilla's website, but if you scroll down, there are a few other results that are not. 
Some of them seem legit, but others are a bit more suspicious. I clicked on the 9th result, and immediately it was blocked by the Blocklist Project malware (found here - https://raw.githubusercontent.com/blocklistproject/Lists/master/malware.txt) due to its root domain.
VirusTotal shows three detections for it, but the root domain had 4 and a poor community rating. A comment from 5 years ago says "It's just a breeding ground for viruses! ".
Norton's community reports are all from 9 or more years ago, and is rated poorly.
Finally, MyWOT has one community rating from 6 years ago that marks it as low trust, and the icon at the top is orange.
All the files from the domain were clean according to VT, but their SHA-256s are diffrent from the offical Firefox downloader. Consitering the signature is from Mozilla, it seems legit.
 If someone knows anything about this domain, please reach out to me via https://github.com/iam-py-test/my_filters_001/issues.
Until more information is known, I will not blocklist this domain.
Domains: mozilla-firefox[.]apponic[.]com
mozilla-firefox-64-bit[.]apponic[.]com
SHA-256:
0ba46a3bda93f50a567887e2c6df97663bf290352654dbf103236d3f6ab0bfab

title: Don't enable Macros; they can infect your computer
body:
Microsoft Office macros are being abused to infect peoples computers with malware; the Dridex malware is spread primarly throught this, and this attack has been used many other times. Not all Macros are bad; many people use Macros for legit uses, and this makes fighting Macro viruses even harder.
Plus, Macro viruses are hard to detect by antivirus scanners (1), and manual analysis is not a viable option.
The real responsibility for preventing this type of malware falls to Microsoft, who (as of May 17th) has failed to patch this. 
To my knowlage, this exploit only effects Windows.

What can you do about this:
1. Do not open attachments from strange emails
2. Do not enable Macros in emails or from other devices
While you may think it is ok to run Macros from a trusted source, they could be infected (some people have been infected via emails from trusted sources) or the address could have been spoofed.
3. Install an antivirus (even on MacOS)
While antivirus software is not perfect, it can stop malware infections. I recommend https://malwarebytes.com, but any good antivirus should do. 
However, make sure your antivirus uses heuristics. Personally, I recommend against using McAfee.
4. Keep your system and all software up-to-date
This is important, as security patches and antivirus updates can eliminate malware.
Normally new Macro virus are detected soon, as the malware reported to https://www.joesandbox.com/analysis/413824/0/html now has 35 detections (https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/692868392ecf930f456d9387ee6132eac61cc07913e668fe6af575f16fbb2392/detection)
5. Don't use Windows
This exploit, and a lot of other malware, primarly or only attacks Windows. Even if you are using a secure OS, you still should follow the above steps.
6. If you think you have been infected, immediately disconnect from the internet and (if possible) manually disable the router. 
Then run an antimalware scan on your device and all devices on that network. 
If you think you were infected by an email from someone you trust, tell them to scan their system for malware.
On Windows, I recommend you scan using your antivirus and Windows Defender (full and offline scans). 
Also download (via another computer if possible) Malwarebytes free (here - https://www.malwarebytes.com/), ADWCleaner (here - https://www.malwarebytes.com/adwcleaner), Malwarebytes antirootkit (beta) (here - https://www.malwarebytes.com/antirootkit), and Hitman Pro (here - https://secure2.sophos.com/en-us/products/free-tools/hitmanpro.aspx).
Links to more information:
https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/hundreds-of-urls-inside-microsoft-excel-spreads-new-dridex-trojan-variant 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macro_virus
https://iam-py-test.github.io/security_research/reports.html#report-Exploit:Win64/msoffice.malwaredownload

title: Testing McAfee WebAdvisor, Norton LifeLock, and FortiGuard against malware
body:
McAfee WebAdvisor, Norton LifeLock, and FortiGuard all have malware website detection systems, so I decided to test them out against a bunch of malware domains to figure out which is best.
I am getting these domains from URLHaus and from my personal antimalware filter. I will put the links at the end of this post.

I will be testing 10 domains from each, starting at the top.

Our first domain gets a Malware rating from McAfee and FortiGuard, and Caution rating from Nortron.

Number 7 was our first miss; FortiGuard failed to detect it, while Norton and McAfee detected it as Caution.

The first part showed that Norton rated all but one as Caution, and McAfee rated 4 as caution. FortiGuard was the only one to have a miss.On to the second test. 

Our first domain from my list is a miss for all. However, the first domain was a domain which had fallen into malware hands and used to be ok. 
Consitering FortiGuard's rating was from 2010 and the Norton community reports (all good) are from 10-11 years ago, these reports are just outdated. Still not great.

The next domain, however, was 2/3 with FortiGuard marking as Domain Parking, and the next was back to all avs. 

Numbers 4 & 5 are dead domaisn, so I am skiping them

 6 was a flop, with all avs detecting it as safe. Note that 6 is a well known - and still online - scam domain.

7 was missed by Norton, which is weird consitering the 7 av detections on VirusTotal and domain-level block by uBlock Origin.

I am skiping to number 11 becuase it is more interesting.
All detect it, and Norton has one community report. Not supprising though. The weird part is that McAfee claims the domain is parked (it is not) but detects it anyway.
12 is a major phishing domain, but still gets caution from Norton. I wonder what Caution really means...
13 is weird; Norton gives it a big red DANGER, but FortiGuard and McAfee don't. To make things weirder, FortiGuard's detection log shows it should be detected, but it is not.
At the end, out of 20, McAfee detected 17, FortiGuard detected 15, and Norton detected 17. This leaves Norton and McAfee tied, and FortiGuard left behind. 
Over all, that is not what I expected. I expected Norton and FortiGuard to be at the top, and McAfee to have more misses. 
 
Due to the low sample size, I am going to test 6 more domains from The BlockList Project's ransomware domains list.
Results: McAfee and Norton detected everything, and FortiGuard only detected two. This is very intresting; these domains are not just your garden variety malware; all of these domain are known ransomware. These stats show that FortiGuard has poorer detection then Norton and McAfee.
Later, I plan on automatting the test and testing far more domains, as to get a better look at what these AVs detect and miss. I also may test domains against other tools.
 Till then, stay safe!


Links:
FortiGuard: https://www.fortiguard.com/webfilter?q=example.com&version=8
McAfee (will need to type the domain into the url bar): https://www.siteadvisor.com/sitereport.html?url=example.com
Norton: https://safeweb.norton.com/report/show?url=example.com

Test lists:
URLHaus: https://curben.gitlab.io/malware-filter/urlhaus-filter-online.txt
My list: https://github.com/iam-py-test/my_filters_001/blob/main/Alternative%20list%20formats/antimalware_domains.txt
Block List Project ransomware: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/blocklistproject/Lists/master/ransomware.txt

title: Testing Google Safe Browsing vs malware and phishing
body:
Google Safe Browsing is the default protection in many browsers, including Chrome and Firefox.
As like my previous post, we are testing Google Safe Browsing against domains from URLHaus (here - https://curben.gitlab.io/malware-filter/urlhaus-filter-online.txt) and Phishing Filter (here - https://raw.githubusercontent.com/curbengh/phishing-filter/master/dist/phishing-filter.txt). 
I will test 11 domains from each. 
The very first domain in URLHaus was missed by Google, but number 2 was detected.
For the malware filter, only one was detected. On to the phishing filter...
On the phishing filter, number 2 was detected, as well as three. Number 5 has a warning, stating that some pages are harmful. Numbers 9 and 10 were detected, but 8 was not.
Just for reference, I tested numbers 8,9, 10, and 11 against McAfee, and it detected all of them. 

Total Detected: 5/22

These detections show that Google Safe Browsing can detect some domains, but that on its own, it is not sufficent protection.
Also consitering it is the default in many browsers, by the time a site is detected by it, it has pretty much met its end.

Stay safe everyone!

title: Testing antiviruses vs malware, phishing, and PUPs
body:
My last two blog posts have been testing McAfee, Norton, FortiGuard, and Google vs malware and phishing, along with scams and spam. 
However, those tests were not great, due to small sample size.
So today, we are testing Google Safe Browsing, McAfee SiteAdvisor, Norton LifeLock, FortiGuard web filter, and Yandex Safe Browsing against a bunch of domains. 
First I will use 15 domains from the URLHaus filter list (here - https://curben.gitlab.io/malware-filter/urlhaus-filter.txt).
Our very first domain was missed by both Google and Yandex, while it was detected by Norton, FortiGuard, and McAfee, and number two was missed by Google, Yandex, and FortiGuard. Things get worse, as 4 was missed by everyone except Norton.
I should note that Yandex keeps locking me out & asking if I am a bot.
At the end of this part, we have none detected by Google and Yandex, 12 detected by McAfee, 6 detected by FortiGuard, and everything detected by Norton. On to the PUPs.

On the PUP test, we noticed a lot of misses even from Norton, who got a high score in the malware test.
Score: McAfee: 1 Norton: 8 FortiGuard: 5 Google: 3 
On the phishing test,
